messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.RecordTypeTest.testLongToString()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
65 :   public void testLongToString() {
66 :     JSType record = new RecordTypeBuilder(registry)
67 :         .addProperty("a1", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
68 :         .addProperty("a2", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
69 :         .addProperty("a3", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
70 :         .addProperty("a4", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
71 :         .addProperty("a5", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
72 :         .addProperty("a6", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
73 :         .build();
76 :     assertEquals( // error occurred here
77 :         "{a1: number, a2: number, a3: number, a4: number," +
78 :         " a5: number, a6: number}",
79 :         record.toAnnotationString());
80 :   }
```

It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```
junit.framework.ComparisonFailure: expected:<...number, a4: number, [a5: number, a6: number]}> but was:<...number, a4: number, [...]}>
	at com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.RecordTypeTest.testLongToString(RecordTypeTest.java:76)
```

The functions covered by passing tests are less likely to contain bugs. This means that if a test case has successfully passed, the likelihood of a bug existing in the corresponding function is relatively low. The passing tests with the highest token similarity to the failing test looks like:

``` 82 :   public void testSupAndInf() {
 83 :     JSType recordA = new RecordTypeBuilder(registry)
 84 :         .addProperty("a", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 85 :         .addProperty("b", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 86 :         .build();
 87 :     JSType recordC = new RecordTypeBuilder(registry)
 88 :         .addProperty("b", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 89 :         .addProperty("c", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 90 :         .build();
 91 :     ProxyObjectType proxyRecordA = new ProxyObjectType(registry, recordA);
 92 :     ProxyObjectType proxyRecordC = new ProxyObjectType(registry, recordC);
 93 : 
 94 :     JSType aInfC = new RecordTypeBuilder(registry)
 95 :         .addProperty("a", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 96 :         .addProperty("b", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 97 :         .addProperty("c", NUMBER_TYPE, null)
 98 :         .build();
 99 : 
100 :     JSType aSupC = registry.createUnionType(recordA, recordC);
101 : 
102 :     Asserts.assertTypeEquals(
103 :         aInfC, recordA.getGreatestSubtype(recordC));
104 :     Asserts.assertTypeEquals(
105 :         aSupC, recordA.getLeastSupertype(recordC));
106 : 
107 :     Asserts.assertTypeEquals(
108 :         aInfC, proxyRecordA.getGreatestSubtype(proxyRecordC));
109 :     Asserts.assertTypeEquals(
110 :         aSupC, proxyRecordA.getLeastSupertype(proxyRecordC));
111 :   }
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.

The failing test covers classes in the `com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype` package. The classes in this package include `RecordTypeBuilder`, `NumberType`, `ProxyObjectType`, `JSTypeRegistry`, and more.

Next, I will check the methods covered by failing tests for the `RecordTypeBuilder` class. I will do this by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_methods_for_class` function with the class name `com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.RecordTypeBuilder`.

The failing tests cover the following methods in the `RecordTypeBuilder` class:
- `RecordProperty.RecordProperty(com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.JSType, com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `RecordProperty.getType()`
- `RecordProperty.getPropertyNode()`
- `RecordTypeBuilder(com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.JSTypeRegistry)`
- `addProperty(java.lang.String, com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.JSType, com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)`
- `build()`

Based on the failing test related to `RecordTypeBuilder`, I can now retrieve the code snippet for the `build` method of the class to analyze the implementation. Let me fetch the code snippet for the `build` method.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The `build` method of the `RecordTypeBuilder` class is responsible for constructing the record type. It checks for empty records and returns the object type if found empty. Otherwise, it creates a record type using the properties.

The failing test `testLongToString` is comparing the output of `record.toAnnotationString()` with an expected string. The failure indicates a discrepancy in the string representation. The error message points to a difference between the expected and actual strings at position "a5: number, a6: number".

To diagnose the exact cause of this failure, I may need to analyze how the properties are being added and formatted in the `RecordTypeBuilder`. To further investigate, I will retrieve the code snippet for the `addProperty` method of the `RecordTypeBuilder` class.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The `addProperty` method in the `RecordTypeBuilder` class adds a property to the record type. It sets a flag `isEmpty` to false, checks for existing properties with the same name, and then inserts the new property into the map. This method returns the `RecordTypeBuilder` instance, allowing for chaining of property additions.

Based on the information gathered so far, it seems that the issue might be related to how properties are added and represented in the `RecordTypeBuilder`. The encoding or formatting of properties may be causing the discrepancy in the string representation used in the `testLongToString` test.

To resolve this issue, one possible fix could involve ensuring the consistent formatting of properties added to the record type within the `RecordTypeBuilder` class.

Here are the methods that might need adjustments:
```
com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.RecordTypeBuilder.addProperty(java.lang.String, com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.JSType, com.google.javascript.rhino.Node)
com.google.javascript.rhino.jstype.RecordTypeBuilder.build()
```

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
